headline: Government Reverses Oil and Gas Exploration Ban as Divisive Crown Minerals Bill Passes Final Hurdle
summary: Parliament was dominated by the final passage of the controversial Crown Minerals Amendment Bill, officially reversing the 2018 ban on new offshore oil and gas exploration. The day also saw the introduction of significant new legislation aimed at reforming the public service and early childhood education, alongside heated Question Time exchanges on public sector pay, energy prices, and the rising cost of living.

topicSummaries.topic: Crown Minerals Bill Reversing Oil and Gas Ban Passes Third Reading
topicSummaries.content: The Government's contentious Crown Minerals Amendment Bill passed its third and final reading, officially repealing the 2018 ban on new petroleum exploration permits outside of onshore Taranaki. The Government argued the move is essential for New Zealand's energy security and affordability, claiming the ban had a 'chilling effect' on investment and led to greater reliance on imported coal. Opposition parties vehemently opposed the bill, arguing it is a regressive step that undermines climate change commitments, risks trade agreements, and gambles taxpayer money on a dying industry, promising to reinstate the ban if returned to power.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Simon Watts (National)
keyExchanges.quote: The ban sent a chilling message to the investment community, halting the very exploration that underpins our energy security and leading directly to the supply constraints and price volatility that we see today.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Dr Megan Woods (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: Either the Government, from Christopher Luxon down, doesn't understand or it is wilfully misleading New Zealanders when it talks about this.

topicSummaries.topic: Major Public Service Reforms Introduced, DEI Provisions Removed
topicSummaries.content: The Government introduced the Public Service Amendment Bill for its first reading, aiming to refocus the public sector on 'getting back to basics'. Key changes include removing specific provisions for diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI), arguing they are covered by other laws, and making all chief executive reappointments subject to a competitive process rather than being automatic. The Government stated the reforms are about restoring discipline, ensuring merit-based appointments, and delivering value for taxpayers. The Opposition countered that the bill takes New Zealand backwards, undermines pay equity commitments, and risks politicising the public service.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Judith Collins (National)
keyExchanges.quote: This bill is about restoring purpose, discipline, and professionalism to the Public Service... it refocuses the Public Service on delivering results, not processes; and it puts the needs of taxpayers—as the people who fund and rely on these services—front and centre.

keyExchanges.speaker: Camilla Belich (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: This is another bill which is walking back New Zealand's commitment—and in the Public Service, it has been since 1960—towards leading pay equity and gender fairness within New Zealand. It is shocking...

topicSummaries.topic: Tense Exchanges Over Public Sector Pay for Nurses and Teachers
topicSummaries.content: Question Time saw sharp criticism of the Government's stance on pay for female-dominated professions, with Labour challenging the Minister for Women on low pay offers for nurses and teachers. The Opposition questioned the value of the portfolio if the Minister did not advocate for fair pay in these sectors. The Government responded that Ministers are not directly involved in negotiations and that current offers are part of an active bargaining process, while also defending its economic management as the best way to support women's financial empowerment.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Carmel Sepuloni (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: What is the point of a Minister for Women who doesn't advocate against pay equity changes, doesn't advocate for nurses to get a fair deal, and refused to advocate for teachers to get the pay they deserve?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Judith Collins (National)
keyExchanges.quote: Well, of course, the Minister is not involved directly—and nor is any other Minister—in any pay negotiations. That would be most unfortunate and wrong for them to be so.

topicSummaries.topic: Energy Prices and Cost of Living Dominate Debate
topicSummaries.content: The Government's handling of the economy faced intense scrutiny, with Labour highlighting stories of families struggling and the Green Party challenging the Minister for Energy on rising power bills. The Government defended its record by pointing to falling inflation and actions to increase competition in the energy market, such as creating an Energy Competition Task Force. The Opposition argued that government policies are not providing relief to households, with the Greens questioning a focus on fossil fuel subsidies over direct investment in renewable energy.

keyExchanges.speaker: Scott Willis (Green)
keyExchanges.quote: What does he think would reduce New Zealanders' power bills quicker: a $200 million taxpayer subsidy for fossil fuel corporations that will not make any impact for a decade, or directly investing in new renewable energy infrastructure and requiring the gentailers to reinvest dividends?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Simon Watts (National)
keyExchanges.quote: Let me be clear: I am not satisfied with the level of competition in the energy market. That is why this Government put together the Energy Competition Task Force, and we're also doing other work like ensuring retailers give a fair price for rooftop solar that's fed back into the grid.

topicSummaries.topic: Early Childhood Education Reform Bill Begins its Journey
topicSummaries.content: A bill to overhaul the regulation of early childhood education (ECE) was introduced, aiming to simplify rules and improve enforcement. The Education and Training (Early Childhood Education Reform) Amendment Bill proposes establishing a new Director of Regulation and moving enforcement from the Ministry of Education to the Education Review Office. The Government, led on this bill by ACT, argued the changes will reduce bureaucracy for ECE providers while maintaining a focus on child safety. Labour and the Greens voiced concerns that the reform prioritises business interests and profits over quality education and the professional status of teachers.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon David Seymour (ACT)
keyExchanges.quote: This is the kind of approach that people want the Government to take. They don't want open slather. They do want regulation. But they also don't want a punitive approach where rules that they may not have known about, that were inconsistently enforced, suddenly show up on their door with a punitive approach that takes away their basic rights.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon Jan Tinetti (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: They're starting to ask us, 'What on earth is going on in your system, where you are putting kids second and putting centre-owners first?'

conclusion: The Government successfully advanced its ideological agenda on resource management and public service reform, while facing a unified opposition focused on the real-world impacts on climate, public sector workers, and household budgets.
